Author: Phineas Kibbey <phineas.kibbey@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Nov 22 17:23:35 2025 +0000

    Add UI button component and utility functions
    
    Introduces a reusable Button component with multiple variants and sizes using class-variance-authority and Radix UI Slot. Adds a utility function for merging Tailwind and clsx classes. Updates globals.css for new color variables, theme support, and animation imports. Adds required dependencies and configuration for UI components.

days.aiSummary: Today we set up *radix ui* buttons from scratch using Phineas' first two commits in Next.js. First, he just dropped a .gitignore for all the dev tools, then—*oh wait*—he added a whole UI button library with class merging and Lucide icons? That’s like writing your own React button template but *using it* instead of third-party ones. The fact that 30% more lines are actually *good* (instead of 99% bad) is the real win.
keyDecisions: Ditch the default Next.js buttons—gives us more control without fighting existing libraries
Use Radix’s vanilla slots + Geist/Lucide for that
learnings: Radix is *not* just a button library. It's a *system*—lots of variants for dropdowns, toast notifications, and more. So many, I’m probably missing the obvious ones!
Tailwind’s `clsx` + `tailwind-merge` combo is a *game-changer*. We’d have to use it like `gs[utils.joinClasses(twClass, extraClass)]) just to make it look good.
Geist in Next.js? WTF?—no one asked for this. It’s weirdly perfect for the slate color palette though, so now we’re all cursed to live with it.

architecturalCallouts.title: The Button Library is a Radical Decision
architecturalCallouts.description: Why start from scratch? Because we *finally* have an elegant solution that feels like it’s built for our project instead of the other way around.

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix + Slot = Magic Button State Management
architecturalCallouts.description: No more complex state logic for button variants—just a simple slot. Like a Swiss Army knife in the dev toolbox!
